questions.text: A 54-year-old male, following binge drinking and heavy meals, was brought to the emergency with sudden onset of severe left sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and subcutaneous emphysema. Pneumomediastinum was present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Esophageal perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumomediastinum with sudden, severe chest pain after heavy meals or binge drinking strongly indicates esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome), requiring prompt diagnosis with a CT scan with water-soluble contrast and subsequent surgical repair.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes a routine laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. During the procedure, the surgeon carefully identifies and dissects the structures within the Calot's triangle to avoid injury to surrounding anatomical structures. The image below was captured during the surgery. Identify the structure as marked:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic duct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When performing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon must identify both the cystic duct and cystic artery within Calot’s triangle to ensure the critical view of safety before ligating and cutting these structures to prevent injury to the common bile duct or hepatic vessels.

questions.text: A patient undergoes a laparoscopic total extraperitoneal (TEP) repair for an inguinal hernia. The image provided shows the placement of the mesh during the procedure. Which technique of mesh placement is being demonstrated in the image?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ laparoscopic total extraperitoneal (TEP) repair for inguinal hernias, the mesh is placed in the preperitoneal space, referred to as preperitoneal sublay , to avoid contact with abdominal organs and prevent recurrence. This technique differs from onlay, inlay, or intraperitoneal mesh placements used in other types of hernia repairs.
  • ➤ preperitoneal sublay

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a recurring pilonidal sinus, and surgical treatment is planned. The image provided shows the surgical procedure performed. Which of the following procedures is depicted for the treatment of a pilonidal sinus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Limberg flap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Limberg flap is a commonly used surgical technique for the treatment of recurrent pilonidal sinus. It involves creating a rhomboid-shaped flap from adjacent tissue and transposing it to cover the defect created after excision of the pilonidal sinus, reducing recurrence risk and promoting better healing.
  • ➤ Limberg flap

questions.text: A patient presents with second degree burns affecting both upper limbs and the anterior chest and abdomen. What is the estimated percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 36%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For estimating the extent of burns, Wallace's Rule of Nines is a commonly used method. In adults, the anterior chest and abdomen together represent 18% of the TBSA, and each upper limb represents 9%. Therefore, burns affecting both upper limbs and the anterior chest/abdomen account for 36% of the total body surface area.
  • ➤ Wallace's Rule of Nines
  • ➤ 36%

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with a painless lump in her left breast that she noticed a few weeks ago. There is no associated redness, discharge, or fever. Her last mammogram was over two years ago, and there is no history of breast trauma. On examination, there is a firm, non-tender mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, with no overlying skin changes or axillary lymphadenopathy. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mammography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women over 40 with a new breast lump, the most appropriate first step is mammography , followed by further investigation if needed (e.g., core biopsy) based on imaging findings. This approach follows the principle of triple assessment : clinical evaluation, imaging, and tissue diagnosis.
  • ➤ mammography
  • ➤ triple assessment

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent a routine colonoscopy during which a small polyp was removed from the ascending colon. Histopathological examination reveals that the polyp is a low-grade tubular adenoma with no evidence of dysplasia or invasive cancer. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Surveillance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients who have had a benign tubular adenoma removed without evidence of dysplasia or invasive cancer, the appropriate next step is surveillance via follow-up colonoscopy. Stool testing for occult blood and serum CEA levels are not appropriate for post-polypectomy follow-up, and surgical resection is only indicated in cases of malignancy.
  • ➤ surveillance

questions.text: A 62-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with signs of sepsis after stepping on a nail several days ago. How would this surgical wound be classified?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dirty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wounds presenting with pus, necrosis, or infection are classified as dirty wounds . In diabetic patients, timely intervention like debridement is crucial due to the increased risk of wound complications and poor healing.

  • ➤ dirty wounds

questions.text: A 34-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle accident is brought to the emergency department with a suspected retroperitoneal hematoma. questions.text: A 50-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

options.label: A
options.text: Poor immunity is a risk factor

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical treatment is required in most cases

options.label: D
options.text: It is a case of dry gangrene

questions.correct_answer: D. It is a case of dry gangrene
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is a case of dry gangrene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier’s gangrene is a form of wet gangrene , not dry gangrene, and occurs due to bacterial infection.   • ➤ Fournier’s gangrene

Other features of Crohn's disease include perianal manifestations and limited efficacy of sulfasalazine in ileal disease.
  • ➤ The risk of colorectal cancer is generally higher in ulcerative colitis than in Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman with a history of unstable angina complains of hematemesis after retching and vomiting following a night of binge drinking. questions.text: A young male presents with painless enlargement of the right testis. On investigation, serum LDH levels are found to be raised. What is the next step in management?

FNAC and biopsy are contraindicated in suspected testicular malignancy due to the risk of cancer spread, with high inguinal orchidectomy reserved as the next step if a mass is confirmed.

questions.text: A patient presents with groin swelling which worsens on coughing. The swelling appears to arise above the inguinal crease, but reaches the bottom of scrotum. On occlusion of deep ring, the swelling doesn’t appear. What is the pathology?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indirect inguinal hernias originate above the inguinal crease and can extend into the scrotum. The occlusion of the deep inguinal ring prevents the appearance of the swelling, which is a distinguishing feature from direct inguinal hernias.
